company.name: Consumerinfo.com, Inc.
company.address: 18500 Von Karman Ave., Suite 900, Irvine, California 92612
company.business_description: Consumerinfo.com conducts business offering consumers the opportunity to obtain credit reports and credit monitoring services through Internet websites and other media. The company operates credit reporting and credit monitoring programs, including the Credit Check Monitoring Service, which allows consumers to access their credit reports and monitor for inquiries, negative information, public records, new accounts, and address changes.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

complaint.factual_background: Consumerinfo.com, Inc. (doing business as Experian Consumer Direct, QSpace, Inc., and Iplace, Inc.) advertised 'free' credit reports on its websites and in radio, television, and Internet advertisements, but automatically enrolled consumers in a paid Credit Check Monitoring Service with a $79.95 annual fee (later $12/month) without adequately disclosing this charge. Consumers were required to provide a credit card number to receive the 'free' report, and were charged unless they cancelled within 30 days, often without realizing they had signed up for a paid service. Additionally, after the FACT Act took effect in December 2004, Consumerinfo continued advertising its commercial 'free' credit reports without disclosing that its offer was not the government-mandated free annual credit report program available at annualcreditreport.com, thereby misleading consumers who believed they were accessing their statutory entitlement.

representations_made.description: Claimed consumers could obtain a 'free' credit report and 'free' trial membership in the Credit Check Monitoring Service at no obligation, while failing to disclose the $79.95 annual fee that would be charged unless consumers cancelled within 30 days
representations_made.quoted_text: 16. In numerous instances since at least November 2000, in connection with the marketing of its fkee credit reportlcredit monitoring service promotion, Defendant has represented, expressly or by implication, that consumers can obtain a "free" credit report and a "free" trial membershp to Consmerinfo's Credit Check Monitoring Service at no obligation, but has failed to disclose or to disclose sdequately that consumers will incw an annual $79.95 fee unless they cancel their trial membership witlun 30 days after requesting their free credit report.

representations_made.description: Advertised that credit card information was required only to 'establish your account,' not disclosing it would be used to charge the $79.95 annual membership fee
representations_made.quoted_text: 12. Prior to mid-September 2003, the $79.95 annual membershp fee was mentioned on the website only in the "Privacy Policy Notice" section on the second Order page, in very small text. In contrast, the "Payment Information" section simply stated: "Your card will not be charged during the fi-ee trial period. However, valid credit card mformation is required to establish your account."

representations_made.description: Advertised 'free' credit reports via www.freecreditreport.com after December 2004 without disclosing that the offer was a commercial promotion unrelated to the FACT Act's free annual credit report program
representations_made.quoted_text: 25. From December 1,2004 to at least March 2005, Defendant failed to disclose or to disclose adequately in their advertisements or on their websites that the "fiee" credit reports they were offering were not associated with the annual free credit report program pursuant to the FACT Act, but rather a commercial promotion, and that consumers cannot obtain their statutorily-mandated free report through Defendant's websites.

counts.title: Failure to Disclose Membership Fee and Cancellation Requirement
counts.representation: Defendant represented, expressly or by implication, that consumers could obtain a 'free' credit report and a 'free' trial membership in the Credit Check Monitoring Service at no obligation
counts.fact: Defendant failed to disclose or adequately disclose that consumers would incur an annual $79.95 fee unless they cancelled their trial membership within 30 days after requesting their free credit report
counts.conclusion: Defendant's failure to disclose adequately the need for consumers to cancel the Credit Check Monitoring Service membership within 30 days to avoid being charged was, and is, a deceptive act or practice in or affecting commerce in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: Unauthorized Charges to Consumer Accounts
counts.representation: Defendant caused annual $79.95 charges to be assessed against consumers' accounts in connection with the marketing of Consumerinfo's Free Credit Report
counts.fact: Consumers did not provide express, informed consent to these annual $79.95 charges being assessed against their accounts
counts.conclusion: Defendant's practice of causing the annual $79.95 charges to be assessed for payment without the consumers' express, informed consent causes, is likely to cause, or has caused, substantial injury to consumers that is not reasonably avoidable by consumers themselves and is not outweighed by countervailing benefits to consumers or competition, and is therefore unfair in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: Failure to Disclose Non-Affiliation with FACT Act Free Credit Report Program
counts.representation: Defendant advertised and promoted 'free' credit reports available through www.freecreditreport.com after December 1, 2004, in a manner that implied association with the FACT Act's government-mandated free annual credit report program
counts.fact: Defendant's 'free' credit report offers were not associated with the annual free credit report program pursuant to the FACT Act, and consumers could not obtain their statutorily-mandated free report through Defendant's websites
counts.conclusion: Defendant's failure to disclose adequately that their 'free' credit reports were not associated with the FACT Act annual free credit report program was, and is, a deceptive act or practice in or affecting commerce in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

provisions.title: Prohibited Business Activities — Misrepresentation of FCRA Affiliation
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from misrepresenting, or assisting others in misrepresenting, any affiliation with the annual free credit report available under the Fair Credit Reporting Act or any other federal law.

requirements.description: Defendant and those acting in concert with it are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting, or assisting others in misrepresenting, expressly or by implication, any affiliation with the annual credit report available to consumers under the FCRA or any other federal law, in connection with advertising, promoting, offering for sale, or selling consumer reports, credit scores, credit monitoring programs, or any related product or service.
requirements.quoted_text: 5 IT IS ORDERED that Defendant and Defendant's successors, assigns, 6 officers, agents, and all other persons or entities within the scope of Fed. R Civ. 7 P. 65, whether acting directly or through any sole proprietorship, partnership, 8 limited liability company, corporation, subsidiary, branch, division, or other 9 entity, including all other persons or entities in active concert or participation 10 with them, who receive actual notice of this Supplemental Order by personal . . I1 service or otherwise, in connection with the advertising, promoting,.o ffering for II 12 sale, or sale of consumer reports, .credit scores, credit monitoring programs, or . . It 13 any .otherproituct, program, or s e ~ creela ting to consumer reports, are hereby 14 permanently restriiined and enjoined from misrepresenting, or assisting others in 15 misrepresenting, expressly or by implication, Defendant's afliliation with the 16 annual credit report available to consumers under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 17. 15U.S;C. $168lj, or any other federal law.

provisions.title: Monetary Relief
provisions.summary: Defendant must pay $300,000 to the FTC within five days of entry of this Supplemental Order; funds will be used for equitable relief including consumer redress.

requirements.description: Defendant must pay $300,000.00 to the Commission within five (5) days of entry of this Supplemental Order.

provisions.title: Change of Notification Address
provisions.summary: The address for all written notifications to the Commission is changed from the address in the Final Order to the FTC's Division of Enforcement address in Washington, D.C.

requirements.description: The address for all written notifications to the Commission is changed from the address in Subparagraph V.C. of the Final Order to: Associate Director, Division of Enforcement, Federal Trade Commission, 600 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W., Room NJ-2122, Washington, D.C. 20580, RE: FTC v. provisions.title: Record Keeping
provisions.summary: For six years from the date of entry, Defendant must create and retain specified business records including accounting, personnel, customer, complaint, marketing, and compliance records.

requirements.description: For six (6) years from the date of entry of this Supplemental Order, Defendant must create and retain accounting records reflecting cost of goods or services sold, revenues generated, and disbursement of revenues.
requirements.quoted_text: 2 IT IS FWU'HER ORDERED that, for period of six (6) years fiom the date I 3 of entry of this Supplemental Order, iic~omection with any business where 4 Defendant is the majority owner of the business or directly or indirectly manages 5 or controls the business, Defendant and its agents, employees, officers, 6 corporations, suc'cessors, and.assigns, and those persons in active concert or 7 participation with them who receive actual notice of this Supplemental Order by 8 personal service or otherwise, are hereby reshined and enjoined from failing to '9 create and retain the following records: 10 A. Accounting records that reflect the cost of goods or services sold, 11 revenues generated, and the disbursement of such revenues.

requirements.description: Create and retain personnel records accurately reflecting each employee's name, address, telephone number, job title or position, commencement date, and termination date and reason.

Personnel records accurately reflecting: the name, address, and telephone 13 number of each person employed in any capacity by such business; that person's 14 job title or position; the date upon which the person commenced work; and the 15 date .and reason for the person's termination, if applicable.

requirements.description: Create and retain customer files containing names, addresses, phone numbers, dollar amounts paid, quantity and description of items or services purchased, to the extent obtained in the ordinary course of business.

provisions.title: Distribution of Supplemental Order by Defendant
provisions.summary: For three years from entry, Defendant must deliver a copy or accurate summary of the Supplemental Order to principals, officers, directors, relevant managers, and employees, and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt within 30 days.

requirements.description: For three (3) years from the date of entry, Defendant must deliver a copy of the Supplemental Order to all principals, officers, directors, and managers with direct or indirect responsibility for matters covered by the Order; must also deliver an accurate summary to all employees engaged in advertising, marketing, sale, delivery, or handling consumer complaints regarding consumer reports, credit scores, or any credit monitoring program.

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Supplemental Order.

requirements.description: This Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Supplemental Order.

provisions.title: Costs and Attorney's Fees
provisions.summary: Each party shall bear its own costs and attorney's fees incurred in connection with this action.

requirements.description: Each party shall bear its own costs and attorney's fees incurred in connection with this action.

duration.termination_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that this Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Supplemental Order.
